Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Digital Platform for Social-Emotional Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is motivated by a software framework that focuses increased attention on improving children's mental health and wellness. For example, the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration recently called for prevention efforts, including interdisciplinary approaches, particularly addressing mental and physical health, through sustainable and coordinated community support. This project offers a unique model that incorporates mental health, physical health, and digital literacy into a platform that provides a cohesive message for transformation, moving children and communities from risk to resiliency by promoting social and emotional learning, positive character development, and overall wellness. This platform accomplishes its goals through the mechanisms of education, health, and social responsibility wrapped in entertainment, supported by data.

This I-Corps project applies a novel software framework to collect data from user engagement (e.g., based on inquiries, content accessed, content created, services performed, etc.) that highlights risk factors affecting children's performance in social and educational settings. This data supplements the P-20 database (P-20 is a state-level, longitudinal, educational, data system intended to capture and analyze student data from preschool to high school, college, and the workforce). The P-20 database focuses on biometrics, and provides a more holistic look at what is happening with children, families, and communities due to the focus on mental health data. This holistic approach provides a multi-risk factorial to identify target communities and specific needs, such as bullying, violence, or substance abuse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the Love in a Big World (LBW) project focused on leveraging technology developed under prior NSF funding for providing information to students, teachers, and parents, about social emotional learning (SEL), and for getting feedback from these groups through their mobile devices. Social emotional learning is increasingly an important aspect of children?s development, particularly in the middle school years, when interpersonal relationships become the focus of behaviors. The project sought to understand what training and technologies are used (e.g., online lessons) in the schools, and how existing infrastructure could be improved to present the LBW curriculum which focuses on integrated SEL lessons. We interviewed 150 teachers, parents, and school principals on their understanding of the importance of SEL among middle schoolers. There was unanimous agreement that middle schoolers' awareness of SEL is impactful and apparent in behavioral change, and that the school is the best place to raise this awareness. In most school districts, existing SEL education is piecemeal and not tied to the core curriculum. Further, training for teachers is lacking, and implementing SEL lessons in the classroom is not standardized. 

The prototype mobile software app we developed is based on the results of our interviews with our broad customer segment, and in particular, our target customer segment of school principals. Our prior-NSF funded projects have yielded a collection of innovative mobile software frameworks that are relevant to our mobile app, and help in effectively bringing the SEL curriculum to the audience, and gather data from the end-users (i.e., students, teachers, and parents).

The broader impacts of the LBW project focus on improving children?s mental health and wellness. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) recently called for prevention efforts that include interdisciplinary approaches, particularly addressing mental and physical health through sustainable and coordinated community support.  LWB offers a unique model that incorporates mental health, physical health, and digital literacy. This platform provides a cohesive message for transformation, moving children and communities from risk to resiliency by promoting social and emotional learning (SEL), positive character development, and overall wellness. LBW is education, health, and social responsibility wrapped in entertainment, supported by data.

The data collected from user engagement (e.g., based on inquiries, content accessed, content created, services performed, etc.) highlight risk factors that affect children's performance in both social and educational settings. This data supplements the P-20 database, which focuses on biometrics, and provides a more holistic look at what is happening with children, families, and communities due to the focus on mental health data.  This holistic approach provides a multi-risk factorial to identify both target communities and specific needs, such as bullying, violence, or substance abuse.

Based on our interviews with principals, who are key to this market, broader impacts of LBW are increased attendance based on improved relationships between educators and students and decreased problem behaviors based on students' SEL skills acquisition.  By providing online lessons for educators, such as school counselors and classroom teachers, LBW offers practical content for meaningful conversations and activities to foster connection between educators and students and students and their peers. As these relationships grow stronger, students have an increased sense of belonging in the school environment which causes them to want to attend school.  Similarly, as students learn about and acquire SEL skills there is a shift in their personal mindset as well as the cultural norms, which contributes to positive behaviors such as inclusion and achievement.
